awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Models for Gene-based Association Analysis of Longitudinal Phenotypes with Sequence Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Longitudinal genetic studies provide a valuable resource for exploring key genetic and environmental factors that affect complex traits over time. Genetic analysis of longitudinal data that incorporates trait variation over time is critical to understanding genetic influence and biological variations of complex diseases.  In recent years, many genetic studies have been conducted in cohorts in which multiple measures on a trait of interest are collected on each subject over a period of time in addition to genome sequence data.  These studies not only provide a more accurate assessment of disease condition but enable researchers to investigate the influence of genes on the trajectory of a trait and disease progression.   This project focuses on the development of novel association testing methods to analyze sequencing genomic data at gene levels.  The research will help provide insights into the underlying biology and progression of complex diseases.

In longitudinal genetic studies and data from the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network, phenotypic traits and genetic variants may be viewed as functional data.  Functional data analysis (FDA) can serve as a valuable tool for exploring key genetic and environmental factors that affect complex traits over time.  In the presence of a large number of rare variants, gene-based analysis is a more powerful tool for gene mapping than testing of individual genetic variants.  This project seeks to develop stochastic functional regression models and longitudinal sequence kernel association tests (LSKAT) to analyze longitudinal traits of population samples and pedigree or cryptically related samples, and to analyze pleiotropic traits.  FDA techniques and kernel-based approaches are utilized to reduce the high dimensionality of sequencing data and draw useful information. A variance-covariance structure is constructed to model the measurement variation and correlations of an individual's trait based on the theory of stochastic processes and novel penalized spline models are used to estimate the trajectory mean function.  The proposed methods and software will be tested and refined using real data sets and simulation studies.  User-friendly software will be developed to implement the proposed methods and will be made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Longitudinal genetic studies provide a valuable resource for exploring key genetic and environmental factors that affect complex traits over time. Genetic analysis of longitudinal data that incorporates trait variation over time is critical to understanding genetic influences and biological variations of complex diseases.  In recent years, many genetic studies have been conducted in cohorts in which multiple measures on a trait of interest are collected on each subject over a period of time in addition to genome sequence data. These studies not only provide a more accurate assessment of disease condition but enable researchers to investigate the influence of genes on the trajectory of a trait and disease progression. This project focuses on the development of novel association testing methods to analyze sequencing genomic data at gene levels.  The research helps provide insights into the underlying biology and progression of complex diseases.

This project seeks to develop stochastic functional regression models and longitudinal sequence kernel association tests (LSKAT) to analyze longitudinal traits of population samples, and to analyze pleiotropic traits. Functional data analysis (FDA) techniques and kernel-based approaches are utilized to reduce the high dimensionality of sequencing data and draw useful information. A variance-covariance structure is constructed to model the measurement variation and correlations of an individual's trait based on the theory of stochastic processes and novel penalized spline models are used to estimate the trajectory mean function. Ten papers are published or accepted, one submitted after revision, and one is almost ready to submitted. The proposed methods and algorithms are tested and refined using real data sets and simulation studies.  User-friendly software are developed to implement the proposed methods and publicly available. Eight software programs are released for research public to use.

 

The proposed projects facilitate causal variant discovery, detect trait trajectory and genetic effects and gene-time interactions of complex traits, and advance the understanding of genetic architecture, pathogenesis, progression, and treatment options of complex disorders. The developments and extensions make it possible to analyze longitudinal traits at gene level by the promising functional models and kernel-based test procedure, and enable the research community to use these more efficient and powerful analytic methods on their own data analysis.

 

Intellectual merits. The proposed aims are highly meritorious because they advance the theory of FDA and kernel-based tests, and overcome bottlenecks of gene level association analysis of longitudinal traits and high dimensional sequence data. We develop stochastic functional regression models and an LSKAT procedure to analyze the next generation functional/longitudinal data.  The methods help to analyze genetic sequence data and to elucidate genetic architecture of complex diseases.

 

Broader impacts. (1) To advance gene discovery of complex diseases for medical sciences and pharmaceutical industry to benefit society and to enhance public health; (2) to disseminate algorithms and software for disease gene mapping, and to upgrade and enhance general research and education infrastructure; (3) to develop interdisciplinary graduate programs to train a new generation of researchers in bioinformatics.

Modified by: Ruzong Fan
